entry.answer: The Mahabharata declares ahimsa (non-violence) as the highest virtue (paramo dharma). It teaches that harming any living being, even for sustenance, violates this principle. The text stresses that compassion for all creatures—whether humans, animals, or insects—is essential for spiritual and moral purity.

It teaches that avoiding violence and protecting life is a moral duty (dharma), as harming others incurs karmic debt, while compassion ensures spiritual progress and liberation.
